node.text:
If you’ve been in a lunch rut like me, just know there’s some Kids Eat in Color magic coming very soon! 🌈 

This community has been asking for it for years… and it’s almost here! 

What is your go-to lunch to make for your child right now?
#kidseatincolor

#lunchbox #lunchboxideas #kidslunchbox #kidslunchideas #kidslunch #lunchideas #healthylunch #schoollunchideas #healthylunchideas #kidslunch #bentobox #bentolunch #bentoforkids #lunchtime #instalunch #lunchtime🍴 #healthylunchbox #packedlunch #lunchprep #easylunch #lunchideas #foodforkids #yumbox #schoollunchbox #kidsfoodideas #toddlerlunch #schoollunch

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Picky Eating Help on September 14, 2021. May be an image of food and text.

node.text:
"I want daddy cereal for breakfast!" my 6yo asked the other day. He already had the cereal out and was getting ready to chow down. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
I swooped in and laid down the law, "You can have some daddy cereal and we need to add a protein food too. That way you'll have energy until lunch time."⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"Mommy says we have to have a protein food too so we have energy until lunch!" he called to his brother. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
They both rolled their eyes, but went along with it. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
We call it "daddy cereal" because Paul (my husband) likes it. I'm just not a cereal person.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Cereal is a food, like any other. And like other foods, they do better in the body in specific ways. If kids are eating processed cereal for breakfast, they will be less grumpy in an hour if they eat protein foods alongside them. (No, milk doesn't usually do the trick)⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Can you find a high protein cereal? Probably, and then it will be okay as-is. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Is cereal bad for kids? No. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Can kids still make their own breakfast using cereal? Yes. But also show them how to get their own protein food to add on (hardboiled egg from fridge, cheese stick, apple and peanut butter, protein bar, whatever works in your house).⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If you're having trouble with picky eating, we have a new free picky eating resource that helps you teach your child to eat new foods - link in bio! Hope you like it ! ⁠⁠
#kidseatincolor⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠

May be an image of 2 people, child, people standing and text that says 'IF YOUR CHILD IS OVERWEIGHT UNDERWEIGHT •Prioritize 20-30 min. family meals Prioritize 20-30 min. family meals Do not discuss weight Do not discuss weight Set meal & snack schedule Set meal & snack schedule •Teach kids to listen to their bodies •Teach kids to listen to their bodies .Start with small portions Start with small portions @kids.eat.in.color'.

node.text:
It's true...we use a lot of the same tools to teach kids to eat regardless of their size. That's because the MOST important thing we can do as parents, is to help our kids have a good relationship with food and avoid future eating disorders. Here are some of my top tools.
⠀⁠⁠
💙No pressure to eat or finish their plate⠀⁠⁠
⠀⁠⁠
💚Learn to listen to their bodies:⠀⁠⁠
- starting with very small portions⠀⁠⁠
- removing distractions from eating (screens, toys, etc.)⠀⁠⁠
- not praising or criticizing based on what they did or didn't eat⠀⁠⁠
⠀⁠⁠
💛Have a meal/snack routine - aim for a meal/snack every 2.5-4 hours (with no food and only water in between)⠀⁠⁠
⠀⁠⁠
🧡Eat together for 20-30 minutes. Start with just a few minutes and work up to this with little ones! We started with 2 minutes. ⠀⁠⁠
⠀⁠⁠
❤️Don't discuss weight or weight loss with kids. Ask your pediatrician not to discuss weight in front of your child.⠀⁠⁠
⠀⁠⁠
🍭Wondering about dessert? Yes, I highly recommend serving dessert routinely (if that’s what your family does) no matter what size a child is! 

If you feel like picky eating is getting in the way of your child eating the right amount for their body, I highly recommend checking out our overcoming picky eating article on our website (link in bio). 
#kidseatincolor⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Picky Eating Help on September 06, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text.

node.text:
From the backseat: "Mommy can I have veggies at my birthday party so my friends can feel better?" ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"Sure buddy, what do you want?"⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"Pepper rockets."⁠⁠
⁠⁠
My kids would NEVER say that these days, but when M was 3, that's what he thought. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
I really like making a strong connection between foods and what they do in your body. It gets more fun as they get older too, you get to learn about all sorts of geeky stuff that goes on in your body. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Have you heard about lycopene before? It's not necessary to know the specifics unless you're a nutrition nerd like me, but the big message is important:⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"Red foods specifically do things in your body. So we include red foods in our meals regularly."⁠⁠
⁠⁠
PS the specs are goji berries. turns out they are loaded with lycopene (and also are $$$) ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If you have a picky eater, you may love our free child feeding guide in our bio @kids.eat.in.color 
#kidseatincolor⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Picky Eating Help on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, food and text that says 'IF YOU THEM WANT THEN SERVE to eat the broccoli @kids.eat.in.color the broccoli routinely'.

node.text:
If they never see it, they will never eat it... ⁠
⁠
Kids need to see foods over and over (and over and over and over). Just today, my little m - who didn't like tomato until he was 3.5 - said "I like these cherry tomatoes." ⁠
⁠
He's half and half on actually enjoying them. Maybe he will never love them. Maybe he will grow up to adore them. In any case, if I stop serving them, I'll never know if he will eat them.⁠
⁠
Same with any food. If we stop serving foods our kids don't like, we don't get to find out if they could have learned to like them.⁠
⁠
Having an exposure approach in your house to different foods, is a great way to help your kids learnt to like new foods (or foods that aren't new, but that they won't eat yet.)⁠
⁠
If you're struggling with a really picky eater, our best selling BetterBites course is open for enrollment through Sunday (link in bio). We cover exposure in depth in the course, but also give you advanced techniques to teach extremely picky kids (think 5 foods) to try new foods. ⁠
⁠
What's the food you really wish your child would eat right now, but they won't yet?⁠
#kidseatincolor⁠
⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Picky Eating Help on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'An 8yo I know: "I don't think school lunches are very healthy..." 1 in 6 kids in the US is food insecure. It's time to talk about how this idea is hurting kids. @kids.eat.in.color 1/9'.

node.text:
School lunches. Lots of questions about them in my DMs this year because of universal free lunches! And as always, lots of opinions. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
My professional stance as a registered dietitian is that school lunches are a solid source of nutrition and meet nutritional standards for kids of school age. They prevent hunger in children who may face hunger at home. They help families who a struggling financially. They help families who don't have time to make lunches as they balance everything. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
And also, some families won't use them for a host of reasons, and that's great too. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
What's not great is if parents are saying bad things about school lunches in front of their kids - or speaking negatively about some of the foods served in school lunches - and then kids turn around and stigmatize kids eating school lunches. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
It's just not okay. It's hurting kids. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Whatever food choices make the most sense for your family, are choices I will support you in. ⁠⁠
#kidseatincolor⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
Sometimes babies can eat a lot. Because they triple in size in the first year of life! Toddlers, however, may eat very tiny amounts of food. Less than babies, even. Because they aren't growing as much.⁣⠀⁠⁠
⁣⠀⁠⁠
This is why the most powerful thing you can do with your little one is to let them decide whether to eat and how much. Don't push them to eat. Just watch them decide how much to eat.⁣⠀⁠⁠
⁣⠀⁠⁠
Maybe your little one eats the plate on the left some days. That's okay. It's also okay if your child eats two bites at a meal and is done. It's normal. It's normal. It's normal.⁣⠀⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Lunch supplies are in the Kids Eat in Color Amazon store: https://www.amazon.com/shop/kidseatincolor⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#kidseatincolor⁣⠀⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Picky Eating Help on August 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'If this isn't working... "It's okay, mommy will be back later." ...maybe this will: "I put Mommy Sprinkles in your lunch so when you eat it, you'll know I'm thinking about you." @kids.eat.in.color'.

node.text:
When Big M went to preschool, he stood taller and never looked back... but it was also a long day. Daycare drop offs were the worst, preschool drop offs were a little better. Still sometimes hard.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
I told him every morning, "I put Mommy Sprinkles in your lunch, so you know I'm thinking about you." What are Mommy Sprinkles? ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
I guess they are those little fleeting thoughts questions I have when I was packing his lunch. What did he like? What did he not like? Is he doing okay at school? How could I support him in a problem he's having? ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Throughout history, a meal made with love, has always been more than just food.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
He loved it. He thought of me when he ate his lunch. He felt that warm fuzzy feeling you get when you know someone's thinking about you. He would ask about the mommy sprinkles. I would act out putting them on his lunch. It was a fun little thing we had. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
We're past mommy sprinkles now. Sometimes I send him little notes because he can read. But I always tell him I'll be thinking about him. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Do you have something you tell your child every day to help them with the separation? ⁠⁠
#kidseatincolor ⁠⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Picky Eating Help on August 25, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text that says 'It's the parents job to choose waa to serve... @kids.eat.in.color'.

node.text:
We just got back from 2 weeks with the grandparents and I'm always reminded of how much grandparents love to spoil grandkids. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
And I don't hate it. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Thinking back to my childhood, I remember many things about my grandparents, including pools of syrup, maraschino cherries, unlimited goldfish crackers (before they were orange). I remember when crunchy Cheetos came out, hot cocoa (fully sweetened) and white toast with margarine before bed, and entire days of TV. All thanks to my grandparents.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Sure, there were also veggies fresh from the garden, trips to the tide pools, unlimited post-it notes, and novel board games.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
But being spoiled was delightful. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
I CAN talk to my parents about food with the kids. We've set a few liberal guidelines that everyone is okay with, but that doesn't work for every family. Sometimes you can't talk to your family, and that can be okay too.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
I rarely address how to talk to relatives about food because every family is so different. I've put together some questions to consider though - and of course there are many other questions that could be asked as well.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
First off, asking yourself if your child is safe is the most important thing. Are your relatives giving your child a food they are allergic to or that is a major choking hazard. That's a big deal. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If it's not a big deal, do you really need to address it? Can you be more flexible? If you can talk to you family and you want to, can you make it positive for them? If you can't talk to your family, can you accept it? Or can you pull in a pediatrician to write a note for you for something that's a big deal?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Sometimes people can't have conversations with their relatives, but they can remake food, bring snacks, or do other things that make life easier for the relative and also bring food choices more in line with your preferences. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
There's no one right way to do this. 😘 ⁠⁠
#kidseatincolor⁠⁠
⁠

Photo by Picky Eating Help on August 25, 2021. May be an image of food and text that says 'It's the grandparents job to do whatever they want @kids.eat.in.color'.

Photo by Picky Eating Help on August 25, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text that says '5 Questions To Ask Yourself Reae to Relatives Feeding Your Child @kids.eat.in.color 1. Is my child safe? 2. How much does this really matter in the big picture? 3. Can have a discussion about this within my family culture? 4. If can have a discussion, what will say my relative CAN do instead of CAN'T do? 5. Can make feeding my child easier for my relative (and also more in line with my desires)?'.

Photo by Picky Eating Help on August 23, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, strawberry and text that says '"YOU'RE NOT ALLOWED TO HAVE CANDY." "HERE'S YOUR LUNCH." @kids.eat.in.color Open restriction leads to candy obsession. Strategic exposure makes candy no big deal.'.

node.text:
"But what if they only eat the candy?”⁠⁠
⁠⁠
It's happened with M&m....rarely. They only eat the "treat." By "rarely" I mean, I can't actually think of a time, but I know it's happened. Why is that?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Because I work hard to prevent them from feeling restricted. As soon as they do feel restricted, that leads to sneaking food, binging, and obsessing about foods. So, if I see anything like that, I bring the obsession food into their meals more. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Also, I make sure that there is food that they usually like to eat in the meal. And that the "treat" portion is child-sized. So, they won't be full if they only eat the treat.⁠ And it’s perfectly fine for me to say “we’ll have more m&m’s on Thursday, there aren’t any more available right now.”⁠⁠
⁠⁠
That said, if a child has been feeling restricted, they may only eat the treat food and obsess about it and tantrum for more. And they may continue to eat large quantities of a treat food if they have the chance, until they realize they are going to be able to eat it often. That may take a while...like several weeks or more, before you see them become less obsessed.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Have you noticed that you eat more of something if you feel like it's limited or restricted?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If you'd like to read more, there's an article in my link in bio @kids.eat.in.color: The Most Overlooked Reason Your Child is Not Eating Food 😘 ⁠⁠
#kidseatincolor⁠⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Picky Eating Help on August 21, 2021. May be an image of food and text that says 'CRAZY SCARY CONTAINED @kids.eat.in.color Freaks out about new cabbage Stays chill about new cabbage'.

node.text:
🔥New food tantrum going down? Large portions can freak kids out. It's way too overwhelming. Small portions may help. Think small. And then smaller...and smaller. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
I call them Kids Eat in Color micro-portions.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Here are some examples of small servings:⁠⁠
- 1 pea⁠⁠
- 1 carrot star⁠⁠
- a pinky-finger size piece of cabbage⁠⁠
- a quarter of a round of cucumber⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Serving small portions is the best way to prevent food waste and also keep exposing picky little ones to the foods we want them to eat.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Is there a food you wish your little one would eat?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
We just finished new guides to help your child learn to try corn and chicken. Link in bio for our new Overcome Picky Eating resource (the page has links to the new guides on it) 😊 ⁠⁠
#kideatincolor ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
